WS153.name: Introduction to Women Authors
WS153.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
WS153.description: Writings by women from various racial, socio-economic and historical backgrounds. Women's choices of subject matter and style. Women's redefinition of literary genres.

WS201.name: Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies
WS201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
WS201.description: Foundational knowledge, theories, methods in women's and gender studies and of women's experience historically and across the globe.

WS202.name: Introduction to Contemporary Feminisms and Gender Theories
WS202.description: Theories of feminism and gender from a variety of intellectual, political, cultural, religious, sexual, racial, ethnic, national, and global perspectives.

WS203.name: Introduction to Methods for Women's and Gender Studies Research
WS203.description: Interdisciplinary research methods for global women's and gender studies.
WS203.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

WS225.name: Language and Gender
WS225.description: Gender and language in societies around the world. Issues such as status, power and politeness in monolingual and multilingual societies. The role of gender in language development, language variation and language change.

WS301.name: Sexual Violence Against Women and Children: Theory and Response
WS301.description: Sexual violence against women and children from theoretical and applied perspectives. Rape, battering, incest and sexual harassment. Intersection of race, class, gender and violence. Individual and collective strategies to prevent or deter assault, race, class, gender and violence.

WS304.name: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer (LGBTQ) and Sexuality Studies
WS304.description: Interdisciplinary study of the history, politics, theories, science, cultures, and communities of lesbian, gay, transgender, queer, and intersex people including a global perspective.

WS312.name: African American Women
WS312.description: Black women in American history. Slavery, the work place, politics, and the Civil Rights movement.

WS313.name: Women in the United States to 1869
WS313.description: United States history through the experiences of women. Gender, family, work, and political activism.

WS314.name: Women in the United States since 1869
WS314.description: United States history through the experiences of women. Gender, family, work, and political activism.

WS316.name: Children's Exposure to Domestic Violence: Promoting Resiliency
WS316.description: Prevalence, context and impact of domestic abuse on children. Strategies for promoting resiliency.

WS317.name: Sexual Assault: Context, Interventions and Prevention
WS317.description: Nature and context of adult sexual assault in the United States. Current interventions and prevention efforts.

WS318.name: Gender-Based Violence Across the Lifespan
WS318.description: Dynamics, risk factors, and community responses to gender-based violence across the lifespan.

WS339.name: Psychology of Women
WS339.description: Development and implications of sex-typed behavior and sex differences. Women's decisions about and experiences of menstruation, sexuality, motherhood, relationships, achievement, employment, retirement.

WS351.name: Gendered Violence and Intersections of Power
WS351.description: Gendered violence from an intersectional perspective. Ways intersecting social statuses such as race, class, and sexuality shape gendered experiences.

SOC351.name: Gendered Violence and Intersections of Power (Interim Change)
SOC351.description: Gendered violence from an intersectional perspective. Ways intersecting social statuses such as race, class, and sexuality shape gendered experiences.

WS353.name: Readings in Women Writers
WS353.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS353.description: Extensive reading in texts by women, focused within a particular national tradition or period or within a particular genre. Critical responses to these texts. Feminist approaches to literature.
WS353.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

WS355.name: Readings in Sexuality and Literature
WS355.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS355.description: Extensive reading in literature drawing on gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, and/or queer perspectives.
WS355.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

WS356.name: Philosophical Aspects of Feminism
WS356.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS356.description: Conceptual and normative issues in feminist theory. Topics such as sexism, oppression, coercion, control, power, equality, personhood, respect and self-respect, rape, separatism, community, intimacy, and autonomy.

WS403.name: Women and Change in Developing Countries
WS403.description: Effects of economic, political, and social change on women in developing countries. Interrelationships of gender, class, race, and nationality.
WS403.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

WS404.name: Women and the Law in the United States
WS404.semester: Fall of odd years, Spring of odd years
WS404.description: Law in the United States as a vehicle for structuring and maintaining women's social roles, and for social change.
WS404.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

WS412.name: Women in Modern European History
WS412.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS412.description: Women in European society, economy, and politics since 1750, emphasizing the lives of ordinary women and the impact of industrial capitalism and the nation-state.

WS413.name: Families in Historical Perspective
WS413.description: Family forms and socio-economic change in Europe and the United States. Gender, childhood, courtship, sexual relations, marriage, divorce, childbearing, and old age in peasant, industrial, and postindustrial society. War, welfare state, and the family. The marginalized

WS420.name: History of Sexuality since the 18th Century
WS420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS420.description: Changing gender roles, sex in the Victorian era, prostitution, pornography, birth control, emergence of homo- and heterosexuality, sex under fascism, the sexual revolution, contemporary conflicts.

WS421.name: Women and Gender in Africa
WS421.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS421.description: Gender-aware and women-centered approaches to the study of African history
WS421.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

WS424.name: Seminar in Queer Studies
WS424.description: Advanced topics in queer studies. In-depth analysis of major topics and developments in queer studies, queer theory, or related interdisciplinary studies in sexuality.
WS424.prerequisite: (WS 304 or approval of department) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

WS425.name: Women and Criminal Justice
WS425.description: Theories on women's victimization and criminality. Women's experiences as victims, offenders, and criminal justice employees. Laws and their effects on the rights of women in the criminal justice system.

WS448.name: Seminar in Gender and Literature
WS448.description: Advanced analysis in literary works within the context of sexual differences or sexuality studies. May include women writers, feminism, masculinity studies, gay, lesbian, or transgender studies. Topics vary.
WS448.prerequisite: (ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368) or (WS 202 or WS 304 or approval of department)
WS448.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the Women, Gender and Social Justice Specialization or approval of department.

WS452.name: Studies in Film, Gender, and Sexuality
WS452.description: Study of films by women and about women, gender, masculinity, or sexuality.

WS456.name: Topics in Feminist Philosophy
WS456.description: Philosophical issues in a framework of feminist politics and critique. Standpoint theories, care/justice ethics, ontological status of genders/races, theories of power/domination, determinism/freedom.

WS482.name: Seminar in Feminist Literary and Cultural Theory
WS482.description: Advanced analysis in feminist literary, critical, and cultural theory and its implications for reading and studying literature.
WS482.prerequisite: (ENG 280 or ENG 353 or ENG 448 or WS 202) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
WS482.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the Women's and Gender Studies Minor.

WS490.name: Independent Study
WS490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS490.description: Individual reading and research on women and gender.

WS491.name: Special Topics
WS491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS491.description: In-depth study of special topic emphasizing women and gender.
WS491.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

WS492.name: Advanced Seminar in Women's and Gender Studies (W)
WS492.description: Guided advanced reading, research, and writing in topics in global gender and women's studies
WS492.prerequisite: (WS 201 or approval of college) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
WS492.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

WS493.name: Internship
WS493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
WS493.description: Application of course work in Women's and Gender Studies through work experience related to women's and gender concerns. Experience in legislative, community, or educational settings in the U.S. and overseas.
WS493.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

WS858.name: Gender, Justice and Environmental Change : Issues and Concepts
WS858.description: Issues and concepts related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Key debates and theoretical approaches to addressing environmental issues from a gender and social justice perspective. Gender and environment issues and processes from a global perspective.

WS859.name: Gender, Justice, and Environmental Change: Methods and Application
WS859.description: Methods and case studies related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Methodological and fieldwork issues from a feminist perspective in international and intercultural contexts. Qualitative and quantitative methods for integrating social and environmental data.

WS860.name: Seminar in Women's History
WS860.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
WS860.description: Political, social, and economic history of women. Major interpretations and research findings. Topics vary.

WS890.name: Individual Reading
WS890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
WS890.description: Faculty supervised graduate level reading in special topics.

WS897.name: Seminar in Feminist Theories, Epistemologies, and Pedagogy
WS897.description: Foundational knowledge, theory, epistemology, and pedagogy in women’s and gender studies from a multi-disciplinary, global perspective.
